channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-15102] HeapMemoryTuner can "overtune" memstore size and suddenly drop it into blocking zone
item.description:
DefaultHeapMemoryTuner often resets the maximum step size for tuning to 8% of total heap size. Often, when the size of memstore is to be decreased while tuning, the 8% tuning can suddenly drop the memstore size below the low water mark of the previous memstore size (which could potentially be the used size of the memstore)
This is problematic because suddenly it blocks all the updates by suddenly causing a situation where memstore used size is above high water mark. This has a very bad performance impact on an otherwise fine HBase cluster.
item.summary: HeapMemoryTuner can "overtune" memstore size and suddenly drop it into blocking zone

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: V0: Choose a conservative approach while decreasing memstore size by choosing min size in the middle of high water and low water mark. The reason to choose it in the middle rather than at the previous low water mark is that if we do so, we will trigger too many flushes at once (because the low water mark will also move down once we bring down the memstore size).

280	        newMemstoreSize = context.getCurMemStoreSize() - step;

281	        if (newMemstoreSize < minMemstoreSize) {

282	          newMemstoreSize = minMemstoreSize;

283	          step = context.getCurMemStoreSize() - newMemstoreSize;

284	        }

285	        newBlockCacheSize = context.getCurBlockCacheSize() + step;

The value of step is modified inside the if block. This potentially would result in mismatch between adjusts to memstore size and blockcache size.

The value of step is modified inside the if block. This potentially would result in mismatch between adjusts to memstore size and blockcache size.

On the contrary, it won't. I modified the value of step deliberately instead of directly manipulating the memstore and blockcache size, because the memstore and block cache size are always adjusted by the value of step.

Say the value of step was 10 at line 1.
In the if block, the value of step is adjusted to 7.
This results in block cache getting less memory than the amount taken from memstore.

ok..I will play
Line 279: step = 10, currMemstore = 50, currBlockCache = 50, minMemstore = 42
Line 280: step = 10, newMemstore = 50 -10 = 40 , currMemstore = 50, currBlockcache = 50, minMemstore = 42
Now, you enter the block
Line 282: step = 10, newMemstore = 42 = minMemstore, currMemstore = 50, currBlockCache = 50
Line 283: step = 8 (currMemstore - newMemstore) , newMemstore = 42, currMemstore=50, currBlockcache = 50

Line 285: step = 8, newMemstore = 42, newBlockCache = 50 + 8 (currBlockCache + step), currMemstore = 50 = currBlockcache

newMemstore + newBlockcache = 42 + 58 = 100 = 50 + 50 = currMemstore + currBlockcache

I see.
Thanks for replay.

To make it more understandable, I will change it to this:


if (context.getCurMemstoreSize() - step < minMemstoreSize) {

     step = context.getCurMemStoreSize() - minMemstoreSize; 

}

newMemstoreSize = context.getCurMemstoreSize() - step;

newBlockCacheSize = context.getCurBlockCacheSize() + step;
V1: Modified patch V0 for better readability.

-1 overall

That's some great checkstyle math there ( 1 = 33 - 33 ). However the style diff is correct there is one.
Findbugs don't seem at all related.

Can we get that one check style issue fixed and then I'd be +1

LOL, the problem reported in checkstyle is not new, the method of interest was already more than 150 lines. I would generally refrain from touching existing unrelated code as part of another patch. But, here, since I am working on the same method, I can very well take care of this checkstyle issue in this patch.
V2: Refactored the method in question to fix checkstyle errors.
